title: Fidelity Investments
content:

Johnson II]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{unbulleted list|[[Abigail Johnson]]
{{small|([[CEO]]){{cite web|url=https://www.fidelity.com/about-fidelity/our-heritage|title=Our Heritage – Fidelity|website=www.fidelity.com}}}}}} | industry = [[Financial services]] | services = {{flatlist| * [[Investment management]] * [[Stockbroker]] * [[Financial planner|Financial planning]] * [[Wealth management]] * [[Retirement]] planning and advice}} | products = {{flatlist| * [[Annuity|Annuities]] * [[mutual fund]]s * [[Individual retirement account|IRAs]] * [[401(k)]]s * [[529 plan]]s * [[investment fund]]s * [[Retirement]] planning and advice * [[life insurance]] * [[Transaction account|checking accounts]] * [[credit card]]s}} | revenue = {{increase}} [[US$]]24 billion {{small|(2021)}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.barrons.com/advisor/articles/fidelity-earnings-2021-51646853970|title=Fidelity Posts 6th Straight Record Profit}} | aum = {{increase}} US$4.5 trillion {{small|(Dec 2021)}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.fidelity.com/about-fidelity/fidelity-by-numbers/corporate-statistics|title = About Fidelity - Our Company}} | num_employees = 57000 {{small|(2022)}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.fidelity.com/about-fidelity/our-company|title = About Fidelity - Our Company|website = [[Fidelity]]}} | foundation = {{start date and age|1946}} (as Fidelity Management & Research) | former_name = Fidelity Management and Research Company | location_city = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] | location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] | owner = {{nowrap| [[Abigail Johnson]] & family (49%)
Current & former employees (51%)}} | homepage = {{URL|https://www.fidelity.com/}} }} '''Fidelity Investments''', commonly referred to as '''Fidelity''', earlier as '''Fidelity Management & Research''' or '''FMR''', is an American [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] [[financial services]] corporation based in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]. The company was established in 1946 and is [[List of asset management firms#Largest companies|one of the largest asset managers]] in the world with $4.5 trillion in [[assets under management]], now as of December 2021 their assets under administration amounts to $11.8 trillion.{{Cite web|url= https://www.fidelity.com/bin-public/060_www_fidelity_com/documents/about-fidelity/corporate-statistics-infographic.pdf|title=Fidelity By the Numbers|website=www.fidelity.com|language=en-US|access-date=2020-09-18}}{{cite web |url=https://www.fidelity.com/about-fidelity/fidelity-by-numbers/corporate-statistics |title=Fidelity launches Crypto support |access-date=September 18, 2020}} Fidelity Investments operates a [[brokerage firm]], manages a large family of [[mutual fund]]s, provides fund distribution and investment advice, retirement services, [[index funds]], [[wealth management]], securities execution and clearance, asset custody, and [[life insurance]].{{cite web |url=https://www.fidelity.com/about-fidelity/overview |title=Fidelity Investment About |date=December 31, 2017 |access-date=March 13, 2018}} ==History== The "Fidelity Fund" became Fidelity Investments under [[Edward C. Johnson II]]; incorporated in Massachusetts, May 1, 1930. During the Great Depression, the "Fidelity Fund" was the only fund approved by [[John C. Hull (politician)|John C. Hull]] in his term in office as Securities Director for Massachusetts because of widespread bank failures in 1930.Moody's Manual of Investments, American and Foreign: Banks, insurance companies, investment trusts, real estate, finance and credit companies Jan 1944 Moody's Investors Service, pg. 754; FIDELITY FUND, INC. Incorporated in Massachusetts May 1, 1930. as an investment trust of the general man agement type. Officers: E. C. Johnson, 2d., Pres., E. C. Johnson, 2nd — Vice-Pres. & Treas.) It’s corporate structure changed in 1946; it’s now known as '''Fidelity Management & Research''' ('''FMR'''). In 1969, the company formed [[Fidelity International Limited]] (FIL) to serve non-U.S. markets and subsequently spun it off in 1980 into an independent entity owned by its employees.{{cite news | url=https://www.irmagazine.com/articles/buy-side/20222/fidelity-worldwide-investment-going-its-own-way-america/ | title=Fidelity Worldwide Investment is going its own way in America | first=Gill | last=Newton | publisher=IR Magazine | date=February 16, 2017}} In 1982, FMR company started offering [[401(k)]] products. In 1984, it offered computerized stock trading. In 1997, [[Robert Pozen]] was named [[CEO]].{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/business/2-executives-get-new-posts-at-fidelity.html | title=2 Executives Get New Posts At Fidelity | first=KENNETH N. | last=GILPIN | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=April 22, 1997}} In 2001, [[Geode Capital Management]] was established to run and incubate investment strategies for FMR. In 2003, it was spun off as an independent company.{{cite web|date=9 February 2006|title=Fidelity Splits Off Geode Capital as Separate Manager (Update1)|url=https://www.aaronpressman.com/writings/geode.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060209185948/https://www.aaronpressman.com/writings/geode.htm|archive-date=2006-02-09}} In 2003, the company launched its first [[Exchange-traded fund|ETF]], called the Fidelity Nasdaq Composite Index Tracking Stock Fund (ONEQ).{{Cite web|date=January 1, 2004|title=Fidelity Launches First ETF|url=https://www.etf.com/publications/journalofindexes/joi-news/1826.html|website=ETF.com}} In 2010, [[Fidelity Ventures]], its [[venture capital]] arm, was shut down, and many of the employees created [[Volition Capital]]. {{cite web | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/stories/2010/01/11/daily11.html | title=Fidelity's venture capital arm breaks off | first=Galen | last=Moore | publisher=[[Boston Business Journal]] | date=January 11, 2010}} In 2011, Fidelity changed the name of its international division from Fidelity International to Fidelity Worldwide Investment and a new logo was introduced.{{cite web | url=https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/operating-chief-chris-rimmer-leaves-fidelity-worldwide-investment-20150602 | title=Fidelity Worldwide Investment COO exits | first=Andrew | last=Pearce | publisher=FN London | date=June 2, 2015}} In 2012, the company moved its Boston headquarters to 245 [[Summer Street (Boston)|Summer Street]].{{cite news | url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2012/11/16/fidelity-plans-move-headquarters-summer-boston-after-decades-devonshire/IV8ggV3lV7tQh39VWogUuI/story.html | title=Fidelity plans to move Boston headquarters | first=Beth | last=Healy | publisher=[[Boston Globe]] | date=November 16, 2012}} In 2014, Abigail Johnson became president and CEO of Fidelity Investments (FMR) and chairman of Fidelity International (FIL).{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/carlodonnell/2014/10/13/abigail-johnson-replaces-father-edward-as-ceo-of-fidelity/|title=Abigail Johnson Replaces Father Edward As CEO Of Fidelity|last=O'Donnell|first=Carl|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20}} In 2018, Fidelity launched a separate entity dedicated to institutional cryptoasset custody and [[cryptocurrency]] trading.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thebusinessofcrypto.com/company/fidelity/|title=Fidelity (Full Data File)|date=2018-10-16|work=Business of Crypto|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-US}} In May 2019, it was reported that the firm would soon be offering cryptocurrency trading to institutional customers.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/06/fidelity-is-reportedly-about-to-offer-cryptocurrency-trading-for-pros-within-a-few-weeks.html|title=Fidelity is reportedly about to offer cryptocurrency trading for pros within a few weeks|last=Fitzgerald|first=Maggie|date=2019-05-06|website=www.cnbc.com|language=en|access-date=2019-05-07}} In October 2019, the company launched Fidelity Digital Asset Services, which will handle cryptocurrency custody and trade execution for institutional investors.{{Cite news|date=2020-08-26|title=Fidelity Launches Inaugural Bitcoin Fund for Wealthy Investors|language=en|work=Bloomberg.com|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-26/fidelity-launches-inaugural-bitcoin-fund-for-wealthy-investors|access-date=2020-09-03}}{{Cite web|last=Rooney|first=Kate|date=2018-10-15|title=Fidelity just made it easier for hedge funds and other pros to invest in cryptocurrencies|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/15/fidelity-launches-trade-execution-and-custody-for-cryptocurrencies.html|access-date=2020-09-03|website=CNBC|language=en}} Subsequently, in March 2021, Fidelity filed for introducing a [[Bitcoin]] ETF with the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]].{{Cite web|last='Bloomberg' Leising|first=Matthew|date=2021-03-24|title=Fidelity Applies for Bitcoin ETF With U.S. Securities Regulator|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/15/fidelity-launches-trade-execution-and-custody-for-cryptocurrencies.html|access-date=2021-03-24|website=CNBC|language=en}} Fidelity's [[assets under management]] climbed 26% in 2019 to a record $3.2 trillion, which helped boost revenue to $20.9 billion and operating income to $6.9 billion.{{Cite web|date=2020-09-29|title=Most Powerful Women in Finance: Abigail Johnson, Fidelity Investments|url=https://www.americanbanker.com/news/most-powerful-women-in-finance-for-2020-abigail-johnson-fidelity-investments|access-date=2020-10-08|website=American Banker|language=en}} In March 2020, Fidelity opened a new investor center in Chesnut Hill, MA.{{Cite web|url=https://patch.com/massachusetts/newton/classifieds/announcements/126342/new-fidelity-investments-investor-center-at-chestnut-hill-square|title=New Fidelity Investments® Investor Center at Chestnut Hill Square|last1=Leary|first1=K. H.|last2=BusinessNewton|date=2020-03-03|website=Newton, MA Patch|language=en|access-date=2020-03-26|last3=MA{{!}}Mar 3}} In March 2021, FMR's operating income rose 4.6%.{{Cite news|last=Krauskopf|first=Lewis|date=2021-03-02|title=Fidelity parent posts 4.6% rise in operating income|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-fidelity-results-idUSKBN2AU1ZJ|access-date=2021-09-06}} In August 2021, Fidelity announced plans to hire 16,000 employees in 2021,{{Cite web|last=Edelman|first=Larry|title=Fidelity Investments boosts hiring target to 16,000 for the year - The Boston Globe|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/2021/08/31/business/fidelity-boosts-hiring-target-16000-year/|url-status=live|access-date=2021-09-06|website=BostonGlobe.com|language=en-US}} including 9,000 during the second half of the year.{{Cite news|last=Baer|first=Justin|date=2021-08-31|title=WSJ News Exclusive {{!}} Fidelity Wants to Add 9,000 Jobs by Year-End|language=en-US|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/fidelity-is-going-on-a-hiring-spree-11630414800|access-date=2021-09-06|issn=0099-9660}} In April 2022, Fidelity Investments announced that it will start offering [[Bitcoin]] as an investment option, specifically in its 401(k) plans by the middle of the year. It is also the first major 401(k) provider to offer cryptocurrency as an investment for retirement savers, according to CNN. However, this option will only be offered to participants whose employers have elected to include it in their plan, as of now.{{Cite web |author=Jeanne Sahadi |title=Fidelity will soon offer bitcoin as an option in 401(k)s |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/04/26/success/fidelity-bitcoin-401k/index.html |access-date=2022-05-08 |website=CNN|date=26 April 2022 }} ==Current operations== ===Mutual funds=== In the 1960s, Fidelity was the first major American finance firm to market [[mutual fund]]s directly to everyday people via direct mail advertising and door to door sales.Peter Lynch and John Rothschild, Beating the Street Simon & Schuster; Revised edition (May 25, 1994) 0671891634 Previously, mutual funds had been marketed almost exclusively to high-income or high-wealth individuals, retirement funds for employers, and/or those already in the finance industry. FMR has three fund divisions: Equity (headquartered in [[Boston, Massachusetts]]), High-Income (headquartered in Boston) and Fixed-Income (headquartered in [[Merrimack, New Hampshire]]). The company's largest equity mutual fund is [[Fidelity Contrafund]], which has $107.4 billion in assets,{{cite web|url=http://markets.on.nytimes.com/research/markets/mutualfunds/snapshot.asp?symbol=FCNTX|title=Fidelity® Contrafund® Fund - NYTimes.com|website=markets.on.nytimes.com}} making it the largest non-indexed fund in the U.S. and the largest fund managed by an individual. [[William Danoff]] has managed Contrafund since 1990.{{cite web|url=http://money.com/money/3926809/fidelity-contrafund-mutual-fund-explainer/|title=Everything You Need to Know About The Fidelity Contrafund Mutual Fund|website=CNN Money}} [[Fidelity Magellan]] is another large equity fund, with $15.5 billion in assets.{{cite web|url=http://markets.on.nytimes.com/research/markets/mutualfunds/snapshot.asp?symbol=FMAGX|title=Fidelity® Magellan® Fund - NYTimes.com|website=markets.on.nytimes.com}} Its current manager is Jeffrey Feingold, who also manages the Fidelity Trend Fund. It was previously managed by [[Ned Johnson]] from May 2, 1963, to Dec. 31, 1971, [[Peter Lynch]] from May 31, 1977, to May 31, 1990, and Harry W. Lange from 2005 to 2012. Under Lynch's leadership Magellan averaged 29% a year, more than doubling the growth rate of the benchmark S&P 500, and remains the best-performing mutual fund in history over such an extended period.The Intelligent Investor, 2003, Commentary on the Introduction{{cite web|url=https://www.ajcunet.edu/story?TN=PROJECT-20121206050322|title=AJCU: Peter Lynch|publisher=[[AJCU]]|access-date=15 October 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226131715/http://www.ajcunet.edu/story?TN=PROJECT-20121206050322|archive-date=26 December 2014}} In 2018, Fidelity Investments introduced a new line of zero-expense-ratio mutual funds{{Cite web|author=Editorial Staff|title=Fidelity Launches Two More Zero-Expense Funds|url=https://retirementincomejournal.com/article/fidelity-launches-two-more-zero-expense-funds/|access-date=2022-01-19|website=Retirement Income Journal|language=en-US}} for individual investors. Fidelity's first two zero expense ratio funds, ZERO Total Market Index Fund and ZERO International Index Fund have since grown to more than $1 billion in assets. Later that year, Fidelity introduced two more zero-expense funds. Together, the four Fidelity zero-expense-ratio equity funds{{Cite web|date=2022-01-18|title=Fidelity ZERO Fee Funds: Here Are the Pros and Cons|url=https://usefidelity.com/t/fidelity-zero-fee-funds-here-are-the-pros-and-cons/145|access-date=2022-01-19|website=UseFidelity|language=en}} provide market exposure to more than two-thirds of industry index assets. ===Brokerage=== Fidelity Investments operates a major [[brokerage firm]] and has investor centers in over 140 locations throughout the U.S. Through its subsidiary, National Financial Services LLC, Fidelity Investments provides services to its correspondent broker-dealers, institutional investment firms, banks and trusts, family offices, and registered investment advisors including brokerage clearing and back office support and a suite of software products for financial services firms. National Financial was the custodian for over $443 billion in assets, in 4.3 million accounts as of September 30, 2010.[https://nationalfinancial.fidelity.com/app/home National Financial web site], About Us ===Benefits outsourcing=== Fidelity Personal, Workplace and Institutional Services (PWIS) is the largest provider of 401(k) retirement plan services with $1.4 trillion under administration{{cite web|url=http://blog.runnymede.com/401k-providers-2015-top-20-lists|title=401K Providers: 2015 Top 20 Lists|first=Andrew|last=Wang|date=16 November 2015}} and $32 billion in total defined contribution assets, as of 2015. Other services provided include pension administration, health & welfare administration, stock plan administration as well as payroll and other record-keeping services. ===Devonshire Investors=== The company's Devonshire Investors arm is a division that gives the owners of the company the ability to make other investments outside its funds.{{cite news | url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/08/08/fidelity-johnson-takes-heavy-loss-his-pursuit-perfect-tomato/1K47Kxicqhrd35i5EKj2II/story.html | title=A heavy loss in Fidelity's pursuit of the perfect tomato | first=Shirley | last=Leung | publisher=[[Boston Globe]] | date=August 9, 2013}} Assets include Veritude, an [[employment agency]] for jobs at Fidelity.{{cite web|url=http://www.veritudejobs.com/|title=Temporary jobs Fidelity Investments - Veritude|website=www.veritudejobs.com}} The company has been a major investor of real estate, owning the [[Seaport Center]] and 2.5 million square feet of office space in Boston.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/09/realestate/fidelity-a-major-investor-in-real-estate-too.html | title=Fidelity: A Major Investor in Real Estate, Too | first=SUSAN | last=DIESENHOUSE | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=April 9, 2000}} It formerly owned [[Community Newspaper Company]], the largest chain of newspapers in suburban [[Boston, Massachusetts]], sold to the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' in 2000{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/29/business/the-media-business-fidelity-sells-newspapers-to-boston-herald-owner.html | title=THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Fidelity Sells Newspapers To Boston Herald Owner | first=FELICITY | last=BARRINGER | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=September 29, 2000}} and now owned by [[GateHouse Media]]. Fidelity has also strategically invested in the telecom/managed services/data center industries, including [[COLT Telecom Group]] in [[Europe]],{{cite news | url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2015/08/12/colt_shareholders_flee_loss_making_biz/ | title=Colt shareholders grab Fidelity offer, declare 'we're outta here' | first=Paul | last=Kunert | publisher=[[The Register]] | date=August 12, 2015}} MetroRED in [[South America]], and [[KVH Co. Ltd.]] in [[Japan]]. Since 2008, all MetroRED ownership has been completely divested. It was formerly heavily invested in commercial lumber and building materials.{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/fidelity-probuild-idUSN0512528620091105 | title=Fidelity's ProBuild investment stumbles -- filing | publisher=[[Reuters]] | date=November 5, 2009}} In 2013, they sold Boston Coach, a [[limousine]] and black-car service, founded in 1985 by Ned Johnson after waiting too long for a taxi, to Harrison Global.{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/05/23/fidelity-selling-bostoncoach-limousine-group-launched-chairman-ned-johnson/pgujsz0a4xNQqDtDMS0uGI/story.html|title=Fidelity selling BostonCoach limousine group, launched in 1985 by chairman Ned Johnson - The Boston Globe|website=[[The Boston Globe]]}} It formed [[ProBuild Holdings]] in 2006 and sold it to Builders FirstSource in 2015.{{cite press release | url=http://investors.bldr.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=925078 | title=Builders FirstSource Completes Acquisition of ProBuild | publisher=[[Globe Newswire]] | date=July 31, 2015}} === Donor-advised fund === Fidelity manages a [[donor-advised fund|Donor-Advised Fund (DAF)]], Fidelity Charitable, in 1991, becoming the first commercial DAF provider. === Eight Roads === Fidelity International (FIL) also runs its own proprietary investing arm called [[Eight Roads Ventures|Eight Roads]]. It is a global platform with 100+ investment professionals across [[China]], [[Japan]], India, Singapore and UK.{{citation needed|date=June 2019}} In 2018, Eight Roads launched a new European fund.{{Cite web|url=http://social.techcrunch.com/2018/03/20/eight-roads-ventures-europe-iii/|title=Eight Roads Ventures launches new $375M scale-up fund for European and Israeli startups|website=TechCrunch|date=20 March 2018 |language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-03}} In June 2019, Fidelity announced it may demerge Eight Roads from its core business.{{Cite web|url=https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/garage/fidelity-considering-demerger-of-venture-arm-eight-roads|title=Fidelity considering demerger of venture arm Eight Roads|date=2019-06-17|website=The Business Times|language=en|access-date=2019-10-03}} ==Investigation about insiders' private investments== A private venture capital firm, F-Prime Capital Partners, managed on behalf of owners and other key leaders of Fidelity Investments, has been described as directly competing with Fidelity Investments public funds. A 2016 Reuters investigation identified multiple cases where F-Prime Capital Partners {{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/usa-fidelity-family/|title=How the owners of Fidelity get richer at everyday investors' expense|website=Reuters|language=en|access-date=2018-02-08}} was able to make investments at a fraction of the price of Fidelity Investments. Because of SEC regulations, investments by F-Prime Capital Partners preclude Fidelity from making the same early investments. The investigation describes that this competition forces Fidelity to delay investing until later and at much higher prices than F-Prime Capital Partners, resulting in lower returns for Fidelity fund shareholders.{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2016/10/05/fidelity-danoff-pay-alibaba/|title=One of Mutual Fund Company Fidelity's Star Managers Made Millions off Alibaba's IPO|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en}} Corporate governance experts have stated that the practice is not illegal, but that it poses a clear corporate conflict of interest. Fidelity spokesmen have stated that they are following all laws and regulations.{{Cite news|url=https://riabiz.com/a/2016/10/14/after-fidelity-investments-and-its-owners-get-blasted-by-reuters-for-alleged-high-level-conflicts-of-interest-morningstar-accepts-the-boston-based-giants-explanation|title=After Fidelity Investments and its owners get blasted by Reuters for alleged high-level conflicts of interest, Morningstar accepts the Boston-based giant's explanation|work=RIABiz|access-date=2018-02-08}} The same Reuters investigation documents six cases (out of 10) where Fidelity Investments became one of the largest investors of F-Prime Capital companies after the start-up companies became publicly traded. Legal and academic experts said that major investments by Fidelity mutual funds - with their market-moving buying power - could be seen as propping up the values of the F-Prime Capital investments, to the benefit of Fidelity insiders. Fidelity declined to comment on this aspect of the investigation. ==Legal issues== ===Document retention fines=== In February 2007, the NASD, a division of the [[Financial Industry Regulatory Authority]], fined four FMR-affiliated broker-dealers $3.75 million for alleged registration, supervision and e-mail retention violations. The broker-dealers settled without admitting or denying the charges.{{cite press release | url=https://www.finra.org/newsroom/2007/nasd-fines-four-fidelity-affiliated-broker-dealers-375-million-registration8 | title=NASD Fines Four Fidelity-Affiliated Broker-Dealers $3.75 Million for Registration, Supervision and Email Retention Violations | publisher=[[Financial Industry Regulatory Authority]] | date=February 5, 2007}} In 2004, Fidelity Brokerage paid $2 million to settle charges by the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] that employees altered and destroyed documents in 21 of its 88 branch offices between January 2001 and July 2002. Fidelity has internal inspections every year to make sure it is complying with federal regulations. Management was accused of pressuring branch employees to have perfect inspections and gave notice of the inspections and that at least 62 employees destroyed or altered potentially improper documents maintained at branch offices including new account applications, letters of authorization and variable annuity forms.{{cite press release | url=https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2004-103.htm | title=SEC and NYSE File Settled Action Charging Fidelity Brokerage Services for Violating Federal Securities Laws and NYSE Rules in Connection with Document Alteration and Destruction | publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] | date=August 3, 2004}} ===Misrepresentations=== In May 2007, NASD fined two Fidelity broker-dealers $400,000 for preparing and distributing misleading sales literature promoting Fidelity's Destiny I and II Systematic Investment Plans, which were sold primarily to U.S. military personnel. As part of the settlement, the FMR affiliates were required to notify Destiny Plan holders who want to increase their investments in existing Destiny Plans that additional shares of the underlying fund can be purchased outside the Destiny Plans without paying the additional sales charges.{{cite press release | url=https://www.finra.org/newsroom/2007/nasd-fines-two-fidelity-broker-dealers-400000-distributing-misleading-sales-literature | title=NASD Fines Two Fidelity Broker Dealers $400,000 for Distributing Misleading Sales Literature About Systematic Investment Plans Sold to Military Personnel | publisher=[[Financial Industry Regulatory Authority]] | date=May 8, 2007}} ==Ownership and management== [[File:Fidelity-Inv-Boston.JPG|thumb|upright|Fidelity Investments Investor Center on [[Boylston Street]] in [[Boston]]]] ===Johnson Family=== The founding Johnson family, individually and through various trusts, owns stock representing a 49% voting interest in FMR, and have signed agreements pledging to vote all their shares as a bloc. [[Edward Johnson III]] was chairman of the group, but was replaced by his daughter, [[Abigail Johnson]]. Abigail was once the largest single [[shareholder]] with about 25% ownership, but in October 2005, it was reported that she had sold a "significant" portion of her shares to family trusts, and that there were doubts as to whether she was still in line to succeed her father.{{cite news | url=https://money.cnn.com/2005/10/28/news/newsmakers/fidelity_johnson/ | title=Johnson still Fidelity successor? | work=[[CNN]] | date=October 28, 2005}} Abigail was named CEO in 2014,{{Cite news |last=Grind |first=Kirsten |title=Abigail Johnson Named CEO of Fidelity Investments |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/abigail-johnson-named-ceo-of-fidelity-investments-1413226082 |access-date=2022-02-12 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=13 October 2014 |language=en-US}} and chairman in 2016.{{Cite web |title=Abigail Johnson |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/abigail-johnson/?sh=1f80fa861c42 |access-date=2022-02-12 |website=Forbes |language=en-US}} ===Employees and ex-employees=== Most of the remaining 51% of the company is held by various Fidelity employees and ex-employees, including fund managers and ex-managers, such as [[Peter Lynch]].Fidelity Investments (March 18, 2013). "Activities and Management of FMR. ''Proxy statement, special meeting of shareholders of Fidelity Advisor Series VII Fidelity Select Portfolios to be held on May 14, 2013''. p. 20. ==Offices== FMR's corporate headquarters are in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], with the largest U.S. operations located in [[Merrimack, New Hampshire]]; [[Smithfield, Rhode Island]]; [[Westlake, Texas]]; [[Dallas, Texas]]; [[Houston, Texas]]; [[San Antonio, Texas]]; [[Mission Hills, Kansas]];[[Covington, Kentucky]]; [[Durham, North Carolina]]; [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]]; [[Cincinnati, Ohio]]; [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]; [[Jacksonville, Florida]]; [[Greenwood Village, Colorado]]; and [[American Fork, Utah]]. It also has offices in [[Canada]] in [[Toronto]], [[Montreal]], [[Calgary]] and [[Vancouver]]. Fidelity Management and Research in 2009 opened offices in both Hong Kong and Tokyo, Japan to add capabilities to its small cap research. In 2004, Fidelity established its first presence in India by opening an office in [[Mumbai]]. However, their offices in India mostly serve back-office function and do not make any investments related decisions. The company has over 4,000 employees in India. Its second largest software development facility (after the United States) is in [[Bangalore]] and [[Chennai]]. Fidelity Investments Ireland was established in 1996 as the European offshore development centre for Fidelity Investments and now employs over 1,000 people with offices in [[Dublin]] and [[Galway]]. Fidelity also has offices in [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Belgium]], [[Italy]], [[Spain]] and [[Switzerland]] and [[London]] for its HR Solution business HR Access. ==Marketing== ===Paul McCartney marketing campaign=== Fidelity has experimented with marketing techniques directed to the [[baby boomer]] demographic, releasing ''[[Never Stop Doing What You Love]]'', a compilation of songs by [[Paul McCartney]]. McCartney became the firm's [[spokesman]] in 2005 in a campaign entitled "This Is Paul".
